tit.e: Old school of tea ceremony of the Ogasawara family
Ko school of tea ceremony of the Ogasawara family
tit.cmt: ここで「古流」とは、「古市」の「古」を取ったもので、「古い流派」という意味ではないと思います。それゆえ、「Ko school」である、と解釈しました。（以下同様です）。
tit.e: Ko school of tea ceremony of the Ogasawara family

sen.j: 小笠原家茶道古流（おがさわらけさどうこりゅう）は、豊前国小倉藩（福岡県北九州市）で伝えられた茶道の流派。
sen.e: The old school of tea ceremony of the Ogasawara family is a tea ceremony school descended in the Kokura domain, Buzen Province (Kitakyushu City, Fukuoka Prefecture).
The Ko school of tea ceremony of the Ogasawara family is a tea ceremony school descended in the Kokura Domain, Buzen Province (Kitakyushu City, Fukuoka Prefecture).
sen.cmt: Domain を大文字にしました。Ko school としました。
sen.e: The Ko school of tea ceremony of the Ogasawara family is a tea ceremony school descended in the Kokura Domain, Buzen Province (Kitakyushu City, Fukuoka Prefecture).

sen.j: 小笠原古流などとも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is also referred to as old school of Ogasawara.
It is also referred to as the Ko school of Ogasawara.
It is also referred to as the Ko school of Ogasawara.

sen.j: 流祖は古市胤栄とされ、千利休や千宗旦らを祖としていない茶道である。
sen.e: It is allegedly founded by Ine FURUICHI, and it is not a school originated by SEN no Rikyu or SEN no Sotan.

sen.j: 同門組織として未得会がある。
sen.e: Its organization of fellow students is Mitokukai.
Its fellow organization is Mitokukai.
sen.cmt: 翻訳を一部変更しました。
sen.e: Its fellow organization is Mitokukai.

sen.j: 古市氏は大和国の有力国人の一族で、流祖古市胤栄と二代古市澄胤（胤栄の弟）はともに村田珠光の弟子である。
sen.e: The Furuichi clan was a group of powerful local lords (kokujin) in Yamato Province, and both Ine FURUICHI, who was the founder, and Choin FURUICHI, who was the second generation head of the school (and a younger brother of Ine) were disciples of Juko MURATA.

The Furuichi clan was a group of powerful kokujin (local lords) in Yamato Province, and both Ine FURUICHI, who was the founder, and Choin FURUICHI, who was the second generation head of the school (and a younger brother of Ine) were disciples of Juko MURATA.
sen.cmt: 国人 を先に表記しました。
sen.e: The Furuichi clan was a group of powerful kokujin (local lords) in Yamato Province, and both Ine FURUICHI, who was the founder, and Choin FURUICHI, who was the second generation head of the school (and a younger brother of Ine) were disciples of Juko MURATA.

sen.j: とくに「一の弟子」といわれた澄胤は、珠光から「心の文」とよばれる茶道教訓を授けられた。
sen.e: Especially, Choin, who was dubbed the 'first disciple,' was bestowed instructions on the Way of Tea called 'Kokoro no Fumi' (Heart's Note).

sen.j: 茶道書『山上宗二記』では数寄名人と評される。
sen.e: Choin was reputed to be a suki-meijin (a master of the refined arts and the Way of Tea) in the book on the Way of Tea titled "YAMANOUE no Soji ki."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処数寄名人：対訳としては確認できません。
sen.e: Choin was reputed to be a suki-meijin (a master of the refined arts and the Way of Tea) in the book on the Way of Tea titled "YAMANOUE no Soji ki."
Choin was reputed to be a suki-meijin (a master of the refined arts and the Way of Tea) in the book on the Way of Tea titled "YAMANOUE no Soji ki."

sen.j: 江戸初期、小倉藩主小笠原忠真が澄胤の後裔である古市了和を茶堂として召抱えたことにより、小笠原家古流と称する。
sen.e: In the early Edo period, Tadazane OGASAWARA, who was the lord of the Kokura domain, hired Ryowa FURUICHI, who was a descendant of Choin, as a sado (person in charge of the tea ceremony), and the school came to be called old (furu) school of the Ogasawara family.
sen.cmt: 古流が古市にちなむことを明確にするには漢字そのものを盛り込むなどの工夫が必要かもしれません。
sen.e: In the early Edo period, Tadazane OGASAWARA, who was the lord of the Kokura Domain, hired Ryowa FURUICHI, who was a descendant of Choin, as a sado (person in charge of the tea ceremony), and the school came to be called Ko school of the Ogasawara family (since the Chinese character for "Furu" [古] in "Furuichi" is also pronounced "Ko" in Japanese).
sen.cmt: Domain を大文字にしました。なぜ古市から「古流（こりゅう）」となったのかを補足で追加しました。
sen.e: In the early Edo period, Tadazane OGASAWARA, who was the lord of the Kokura Domain, hired Ryowa FURUICHI, who was a descendant of Choin, as a sado (person in charge of the tea ceremony), and the school came to be called Ko school of the Ogasawara family (since the Chinese character for "Furu" [古] in "Furuichi" is also pronounced "Ko" in Japanese).

sen.j: 忠真は大名茶人として知られていた。
sen.e: Tadazane was a renowned feudal load (daimyo) and a master of the tea ceremony.
Tadazane was a renowned daimyo (Japanese feudal load) and a master of the tea ceremony.
sen.cmt: 大名 を先に表記しました。
sen.e: Tadazane was a renowned daimyo (Japanese feudal load) and a master of the tea ceremony.

sen.j: 以後、古市家代々は小笠原候茶堂として幕末まで仕えており、江戸後期の古市宗理の頃にはとくに流儀の隆盛が見られた。
sen.e: The Furuichi family succeeded the position of Marquis Ogasawara's sado for generations thereafter until the end of the Edo period, with the culmination of the school occuring around the time of Munemichi FURUICHI in the late Edo period.

The Furuichi family succeeded the position of the sado for the lord of Ogasawara for generations thereafter until the end of the Edo period, with the culmination of the school occurring around the time of Munemichi FURUICHI in the late Edo period.
sen.cmt: 小笠原候→lord of Ogasawara としました。スペルを修正しました。
sen.e: The Furuichi family succeeded the position of the sado for the lord of Ogasawara for generations thereafter until the end of the Edo period, with the culmination of the school occurring around the time of Munemichi FURUICHI in the late Edo period.

sen.j: 他の大名茶と同様、古市家が扶持離れをした明治以降は下火となった。
sen.e: Like other daimyo cha (tea practiced by feudal lords), the school declined after the Furuichi family left the lord in the Meiji period.

sen.j: だが、昭和48年に小倉藩主家である小笠原総領家第32代当主小笠原忠統を古流総裁に迎え、流儀の発展をはかった。
sen.e: But in 1973, Tadamune OGASAWARA, who was the 32th head of the main Ogasawara family, which is the family of lord of Kokura Domain, assumed the position of the president of the old school to promote development of the school.

sen.j: 平成4年には忠統は総裁兼務の家元に就任。
sen.e: In 1992, Tadamune concurrently assumed the position of iemoto (the head family of a school).

sen.j: 現在の家元は小笠原総領家第33代当主の小笠原長雅。
sen.e: The present iemoto is Nagamasa OGASAWARA, who is the 33th head of the main Ogasawara family.
